content: If you have made a copy of the entire "Thunderbird" folder before upgrading to Win12 you now may - Thunderbird shut down - replace the actual "Thunderbird" folder in ...\AppData\Roaming\... with the saved copy and restart TB.
creator: Mapenzi

content: Thanks for your reply. Before I do a replace, I’d like to give a description of the folder Thunderbird that I created just prior to the move to W11. There is something that puzzles me and causes me to hesitate. I will begin with a somewhat detailed description of the Thunderbird folder (that you can probably skip over) and then a cause and question about my hesitation. The Thunderbird folder was one of the subfolders of C:\Users\rsuth\AppData\Roaming\. It is 8.94 Gb, containing 72 subfolders and 11067 files. Two of the files are installs.ini and profiles.ini. Four of the subfolders are Crash Reports (1010 bytes, 101 files, subfolder events), Pending Pings (empty), Profiles (5.16 Gb, 467 files, 33 subfolders; one of the subfolders is odp….default, containing the files times and json, the other subfolder is gqf….default-release, containing many files and subfolders), and another subfolder named Thunderbird. This second named Thunderbird (3.77 Gb, 34 subfolders, 497 files) has three subfolders: Crash Reports, Pending Pings, and Profiles as well as the files installs.ini and profiles.ini. My hesitation is based upon a folder named Thunderbird containing a subfolder with the same name. So my questions is this: does one Thunderbird folder containing a subfolder with the same name effect the instructions you gave to shut down Thunderbird, then replace the current Thunderbird folder with the first one I described above, or does something else/different need to be done before any replacing?
creator: I_Rufus

content: A folder Thunderbird containing a sub-folder named Thunderbird is not normal. It means that someone has made a faulty copy & paste action with another (?) Thunderbird folder in the file explorer. Does the sub-folder Thunderbird contain a Mail and an ImapMail folder? Anyhow you can proceed to the replacement as I indicated in my first reply. If it succeeds we'll explore the sub-folder Thunderbird a bit later.
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Definitely possible that I screwed up something regarding saving folders back at the start of my problems.

I used file explorer to search the Thunderbird sub-folder for a Mail folder and an ImapMail folder. No matches found for ImapMail. The search for the word mail found two folders named Mail. The date modified on each was only 1 minute different than the other. (Actually, the search found two more folders with mail in their titles: mail.comcast.net. Their dates modified were only 1 minute apart.) I looked at the properties of the two Mail folders. The properties were not the same. 3.70 Gb for 1, 5 Gb for the other; 59 files and 63 files; 6 folders both.

So then I tried your suggestion: “Thunderbird shut down - replace the actual "Thunderbird" folder in ...\AppData\Roaming\... with the saved copy and restart TB.” I did that and then loaded Thunderbird - and it appeared with most – if not all – of the settings that had been there before the W11 upgrade! After a moment’s pause, Thunderbird, as usual, asked me to enter my password so that I could download my email from Comcast. I did so. Thunderbird’s response was that the password was incorrect, try again. So I did – and got the same result. I then shut down Thunderbird , my other open programs and the computer itself. After a few minutes, I rebooted and loaded Thunderbird. It works!! It looks like what I remember from before the W11 problem. The settings, folders, etc. are what I remember – or very close.

So I begin by saying thank you for the help that you’ve given. I feel comfortable again, but with a tiny bit of hesitation. I want to wait until tomorrow morning, after a complete night’s shutdown, before I try Thunderbird again. Right now I feel that all will be fine, but I will wait until then before I click the “Solved the problem” button.
creator: I_Rufus

content:
Mixed results. The settings and folders seem to be back as they were before the problem began. There seems to be a new problem that I assume is somehow related to the original and, possibly, to the fix that just occurred. The new problem relates to speed. When I first start Tbird, it takes a fairly long time for the window to pop up and ask me to enter my password. After I enter it, it still takes a fairly long time to download whatever new mail might be out there. While all this is happening, the little blue line in the lower right corner is active.

Another mystery: I access my comcast email account using Firefox and I see a couple of new emails in the list. I don’t open them. I just log out of my comcast account. When I try to download them via Tbird (Get Messages), Tbird tells me there are no new messages. I’m not even sure what to ask next. Any ideas?

content:
Today I used Tbird several times. A couple of times I closed Tbird down and reopened it at a later time. A couple of times I closed Tbird, then restarted my computer. A couple of times, I closed Tbird, shut down my computer, then waited several minutes before starting again. And as I was writing this, about to tell you what I thought was happening, something different happened. I ask your patience. I plan to sit in front of my computer for the next 20 – 30 minutes, looking at the screen, trying to get something to happen, noting what happens, and then sharing it with you. (If nothing happens during this time span, then I plan to do something similar tomorrow morning but for a longer time.

Here’s an example of something that I thought might be a problem. Earlier, using Firefox to access my Comcast email account, I saw a message that was timed at 5:30 PM. I switched to Tbird and the message wasn’t there. I clicked Get Messages; no response. I tried again several minutes later and the message appeared on Tbird at 5:38. I’m confused. What I plan to do tonight and/or tomorrow morning, is to try to copy what I have done today: look at the list of emails on Comcast, using a web browser, then trying to download the email using Tbird. Will all the emails download from Comcast? If not, when will the remainder show up on Tbird? Please give me a little more patience. Thanks.
creator: I_Rufus

content:
Events from today.

1. Turned on computer. Used Edge to go to Comcast website and view my email. Ran Tbird a minute or so later. The request for my password, which used to appear almost immediately, did not appear. I decided to try pressing Get Messages. Nothing changed. Three minutes later the password request appeared. I entered it. Nothing happened. Three minutes later, nothing still happening, I closed Tbird (as well as Edge).

2. Half hour later. Ran Edge to Comcast to view email. Start Tbird. No PW request. I noticed the blue line in lower right corner was active. (I didn’t look there the first time.) About 3 minutes later the PW request appeared. I entered it. No more blue line. I clicked Get Messages; the blue line appeared. Mail was downloaded. I compared the mails listed on the Comcast site and the ones just downloaded to Tbird. They were not exactly the same. One piece of email shown on Comcast did not appear via Tbird.

3. About 1.5 hours later, I repeated Edge and Tbird. Edge/Comcast showed 2 new emails. Using Tbird as in #2 (waiting for PW request, then Get Messages), the same two, new messages were downloaded. The Tbird time was about two minutes from start to delivery.
creator: I_Rufus

content: Your Inbox contains 194 messages for a size of 3.9 GB!! Did you ever compact your Inbox folder? https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/compacting-folders
creator: Mapenzi

content: Two things: Earlier today, the first thing I did, after turning on my computer, was to start TBird. There was an immediate quest for my PW, which I entered. The thin blue line continued for about a minute, then an error message appeared, about a failure to connect. Nevertheless, I clicked Get messages. About three minutes later, the new email was delivered. Tbird seemed to work fine from then on. I have used Tbird for a long time, perhaps 15 or 20 years. I have never had a problem/error relating to the number/size of emails in my various folders, inbox being one of a dozen. Until I read your message, I was not aware of “compact”. I did some reading at the linked site and, honestly, I will need to reread it once or twice more for it to sink in. One aspect that caught my attention was the option to select to automatically compact in the future. I think that, perhaps, that option was the default whenever it was that I initially installed Tbird. In any case, I thought I would look at my compact settings. I started with the section of the page headed “How can I configure compact?” The very next line begins with the symbol for the Tbird menu (3 horiz lines). The menu on my Tbird page does not have a Preferences option. I explored a little and found the section at Settings > Network & Disk Space. I looked at my hard drive and saw that I have more than 700Gb of free space, so I do not feel the need to compact. But it was interesting to read. The next time I restart my computer, I will look to see if what I described at the top of this message happens again. Either way, I will post it here.

content: This post appears to be in the Help/Support Forums/Thunderbird/. Is there another place I should be asking this question? I don't understand markwarner22's reply. My problem is: 100s of spam emails come into my thunderbird account from my Comcast.net email address that never appear in the Xfinity webmail page. When I go to Xfinity's webmail webpage, none of these spam emails appear anywhere. Neither in its Inbox or Spam folder. They're just not there. But somehow, when Thunderbird "retrieves" email from that account, it "retrieves" all these invisible spam emails from somewhere. It appears Thunderbird gets them before Xfinity (Comcast) filters them out. BTW, I have no filters set up on the Xfinity webpage. So however Xfinity gets rid of the spam, it does it on its own.
creator: ralphco

content:
Hi Ralphco,

Layman's guess: Comcast is adding headers to identify those messages as junk, but Thunderbird ignores those headers unless you tell it what to do.

In account settings - junk settings, is "Trust junk mail headers set by:" selected? If so, which filter is selected in the drop-down list?

You may have to contact Comcast to learn which spam filter they use, and hope that it is in the drop-down list.

Rick

content: This appears to be a file problem. When thunderbird closes, it updates the prefs.js file with that information. If the file is read-only or otherwise unavailable, the result is as you describe. this may be an antivirus or VPN or firewall interferring. You may also see multiple prefs files, such as prefs-1.js, etc. If unfamiliar with accessing profile, you can do this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' on left side and click 'open folder' - you are now in profile. exit thunderbird - if there are multiple entries for prefs.js, rename the one with highest number to prefs.js after deleting the original. That may work.
creator: davidsk

content:
Nechápu termíny "přeuložení" ani jak se může "obrázek změnit". To jako sám od sebe? - když člověk přeuloží obrázek jiným obrázkem , upraveným, nebo úplně jiným (nahradí jej se stejným názvem)

  • Podpis-obrázek-html-vnímající změny

Jaké změny asi tak může vnímat obrázek? - asi to, že je úplně jinej. Ve složce nahradím obrázek jiným se stejným názvem a automaticky se mi změní v email podpisu.

  • Když vytvořím html na disku, tak obrázek načte, ale jen jako čistý obdélník.

Dost pravděpodobně se jedná o chybnou cestu k obrázku, diakritika v názvu, nebo mezery. - Zkoušel jsem asi 10 různých cest. Když udělám chybu v cestě, obrázek to vůbec nenačte. Při správné cestě jej načte viz výše.
creator: jarda.nevecny

content:
Kunt u een voorbeeld delen (waar de privacygevoelige gegevens uit zijn verwijderd)?

U zou de volgende zaken eens kunnen proberen:

  • De map waarin de berichten staan repareren: klik met uw rechtermuisknop op de map, selecteer Eigenschappen en vervolgens Map repareren.
  • Een nieuw profiel aanmaken: probeer of u in een ‘vers’ profiel hetzelfde probleem ervaart.
  • Als u opnieuw installeren geen bezwaar zou vinden, verwijder dan Thunderbird en verwijder ook uw profielmappen. Bij een herinstallatie zonder verwijdering ‘ziet’ het programma namelijk het oude profiel en gebruikt het dat om de instellingen e.d. te herstellen, en als daar de fout in zit, dan krijgt u die weer terug.

De twee laatste bovenstaande punten werken prima als u IMAP gebruikt; bij POP ziet u uw eerder opgehaalde berichten niet meer terug.
creator: markh2

content: The problem was I began to work (cleaning, filing...) on my moved data for about 10 days before seeing my local folder did not follow. The result was I mixed 115 shape folders and 123 shape under the 123 control. The folder management is not the same in both releases, and cannot be mixed.( the notes themselves are not concerned). Folder operations could not be executed (empty the thrash, compact folders, create new sub-folder: All operations I only tryed 10 days after the move...) The solution was to reinstall the 115, starting with 115 profile, create folders where to save the 10 days notes. update to 118, then 123. Back to 123 profile save 10 days activity in the above created folders. Then back to 115 profile, move back the 10 days notes to their original folders to get back the 123 profile contents. In french, we say : "ouf !!! "
creator: cuq1

content:
The error and the visual disappearance of your mail were probably directly related. Do you have an exclusion in your antivirus program for the Thunderbird profile folder?

That is the most common issue with compacting. Antivirus programs lock files and you get messages about disk space because the program can not make the file bigger because it is locked by the antivirus. An exclusion to keep the interfering program away while Thunderbird is running is the simply cure.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: I added an exclusion to my Norton for the whole Profiles directory. Many days later and after shutting down and starting up my laptop many times, Thunderbird asked to compact my Inbox and the same error occurred again. So this appears to be something other than AV software interference.
creator: pdupuis

content:
I'm also sometimes seeing the blank Inbox after compacting was triggered automatically. But it isn't exactly reproducible. And I have no idea what triggers this behavior. A Thunderbird restart is needed to clear this up. I'm also seeing this on Linux, so I do agree, the blank Inbox effect has got nothing to do with anti-virus software. Unfortunately without exact steps to reproduce there is no point raising a bug. I do not see any error messages in connection with compacting.

This time I got an error (sorry I did not save the exact error message) but it was that the folder could not be compacted due to an error, possibly not enough disk space and to check and make more space available.

This kind of error may very well be caused by anti-virus software.
creator: christ1

You have opened the "Chat" tab in the tab bar! Go to the Spaces Menu button in the upper left corner of the toolbar and select "Mail" or hit the Cmd+1 keys. content: Thunderbird doesn't have an explicit blacklist, but you can create a filter that deletes all messages where from contains @dominio.
creator: davidsk

content: Pero cómo?, cuando un dominio cada día cambia el nombre con letras de la "a" a la "z" @dominio, ejemplo, hoy llega "hgtrup@dominio.com", otro día "rmspty@el mismo dominio", cómo eliminar todos de ese mismo dominio?
creator: toni40

content: Specify only the letters that are the same. For example, of you receive emails from @domain, @xxxdomain, @domain23, etc. just set the filter for domain as those six characters are in each. If I am not understanding, please give some examples. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: Algunos ejemplos: itpizkv@finhiking.de idyabbx@finhiking.de ylrenxc@finhiking.de ypyomsc@finhiking.de Vuelvo a formular la pregunta.........cómo puedo filtrar el dominio "@finhiking.de" indistintamente del nombre que le preceda. Gracias.
creator: toni40

content: Here is a sample. The word 'contains' limits the match to just those characters. See attached screenshot
creator: davidsk

content:
What happens if you add the smtp server in Account Settings, Outgoing Server (SMTP), (bottom of left pane), then select the relevant account in the left pane of Account Settings and select the new smtp in the Outgoing Server (SMTP) drop-down in the right pane?

If the account can't be added the normal way, go Offline by clicking the icon at the left end of the status bar, start the New Account dialog, then choose Manual config. and Advanced config. to enter the incoming server settings and the new smtp. After the setup, click the Offline/Online icon to go back online.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Hi,

"Move my address to another provider" would seem to mean "move my e-mail account to another e-mail service provider because I am giving up on Thunderbird".

But giving up on Thunderbird would mean that you need a different e-mail client or web app, not a new service provider.

Do you want a new e-mail service provider or a new way to access your messages or both?

Rick
creator: user213815874572776100201782415079883066567

content: Do you need to click in the date heading so the email in your inbox is sorted in descending order? Newest at the top of the list

content: Go to Settings > General > Thunderbird Start Page > Location and delete the URL
